mentions.snippet: The FSB and GRU coordinated Operation Nightfall in Eastern Ukraine during July 2014.
mentions.context: First sentence naming the event and placing it in Eastern Ukraine (July 2014); identifies the operation coordinated by FSB and GRU.

mentions.snippet: The FSB and GRU coordinated Operation Nightfall in Eastern Ukraine during July 2014.
mentions.context: First mention of FSB as one of the agencies coordinating Operation Nightfall.

mentions.snippet: The FSB and GRU coordinated Operation Nightfall in Eastern Ukraine during July 2014.
mentions.context: First mention of GRU as the other agency coordinating Operation Nightfall.

mentions.snippet: Colonel Igor Petrov (FSB) and Major Sergei Ivanov (GRU) led the operation from Moscow, with direct support from the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade based in Kursk.
mentions.context: Introduced as FSB operational lead of Operation Nightfall; traveled from Moscow and coordinated with 53rd Brigade in Kursk.

mentions.snippet: Colonel Igor Petrov (FSB) and Major Sergei Ivanov (GRU) led the operation from Moscow, with direct support from the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade based in Kursk.
mentions.context: Introduced as GRU lead of Operation Nightfall; traveled from Moscow and coordinated with 53rd Brigade in Kursk.

mentions.snippet: Colonel Igor Petrov (FSB) and Major Sergei Ivanov (GRU) led the operation from Moscow, with direct support from the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade based in Kursk.
mentions.context: Identified as the command location from which the operation was led.

mentions.snippet: Colonel Igor Petrov (FSB) and Major Sergei Ivanov (GRU) led the operation from Moscow, with direct support from the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade based in Kursk.
mentions.context: Named as the military unit providing direct support and the Buk missile system; based in Kursk.

mentions.snippet: Colonel Igor Petrov (FSB) and Major Sergei Ivanov (GRU) led the operation from Moscow, with direct support from the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade based in Kursk.
mentions.context: Named as the base location of the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade and origin of the Buk missile system.

mentions.snippet: The operation utilized a Buk missile system, which was transported from Russia to Ukraine to support separatist forces in Donetsk.
mentions.context: Describes the weapon system central to the operation and its transport from Russia to Ukraine (Donetsk).

mentions.snippet: The operation utilized a Buk missile system, which was transported from Russia to Ukraine to support separatist forces in Donetsk.
mentions.context: Country of origin for the Buk missile system transport into Ukraine.

mentions.snippet: The FSB and GRU coordinated Operation Nightfall in Eastern Ukraine during July 2014.
mentions.context: Places the operation in Eastern Ukraine.

mentions.snippet: The operation utilized a Buk missile system, which was transported from Russia to Ukraine to support separatist forces in Donetsk.
mentions.context: Named as the operational area where the Buk was deployed to support separatists.

mentions.snippet: Lieutenant Oleg Markov (FSB) and Agent Anna Volkova (FSB) provided tactical support to Colonel Petrov throughout the operation.
mentions.context: Introduced as an FSB tactical supporter who accompanied the Buk deployment.

mentions.snippet: Lieutenant Oleg Markov (FSB) and Agent Anna Volkova (FSB) provided tactical support to Colonel Petrov throughout the operation.
mentions.context: Introduced as an FSB agent providing tactical and intelligence support in the operation.

mentions.snippet: On the GRU side, Captain Dmitri Sokolov from Unit 29155 worked alongside Major Ivanov to coordinate military assets.
mentions.context: Introduced as a GRU officer from Unit 29155 coordinating technical/military assets for the operation.

mentions.snippet: On the GRU side, Captain Dmitri Sokolov from Unit 29155 worked alongside Major Ivanov to coordinate military assets.
mentions.context: Named as the GRU unit to which Captain Sokolov is attached; involved in coordination.

mentions.snippet: On July 15, 2014, Colonel Igor Petrov and Major Sergei Ivanov traveled together from Moscow to Rostov-on-Don.
mentions.context: First operational movement: Petrov and Ivanov traveled from Moscow to Rostov-on-Don; Rostov functions as forward base.

mentions.snippet: Bellingcat and The Insider conducted parallel investigations into Operation Nightfall.
mentions.context: Named as one of the investigative organizations that examined Operation Nightfall.

mentions.snippet: Bellingcat and The Insider conducted parallel investigations into Operation Nightfall.
mentions.context: Named as the investigative outlet that conducted parallel investigation alongside Bellingcat.

mentions.snippet: Eliot Higgins led the Bellingcat investigation team, focusing on open-source intelligence analysis.
mentions.context: Named as lead of the Bellingcat investigative team, focusing on open-source intelligence work.

mentions.snippet: Christo Grozev directed The Insider's efforts, specializing in Russian intelligence operations.
mentions.context: Named as director of The Insider's investigation, specializing in Russian intelligence operations.

mentions.snippet: Eliot Higgins and Christo Grozev utilized social media evidence from Twitter and VKontakte to track the Buk convoy's movement from Kursk through Rostov to Donetsk.
mentions.context: Platform used as a source of social media evidence for tracking the Buk convoy.

mentions.snippet: Eliot Higgins and Christo Grozev utilized social media evidence from Twitter and VKontakte to track the Buk convoy's movement from Kursk through Rostov to Donetsk.
mentions.context: Social media platform used by investigators (The Insider and Bellingcat) to trace the convoy and accounts linked to units.

mentions.snippet: **Authors**: Test Investigation Team
mentions.context: Listed as the (synthetic) authors of the document.

mentions.snippet: Eliot Higgins led the Bellingcat investigation team, focusing on open-source intelligence analysis.
mentions.context: Describes the investigative methodology used by Bellingcat and Higgins (OSINT).

mentions.snippet: Eliot Higgins pioneered techniques for tracking the Buk missile system through Twitter geotagging, while Christo Grozev identified key VKontakte accounts linked to the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade and Unit 29155.
mentions.context: Investigative technique (Twitter geotagging) used to track the Buk missile system movement.

mentions.snippet: Bellingcat analyzed photographic evidence, while The Insider obtained testimony from witnesses in Moscow, Kursk, and Rostov.
mentions.context: One of the evidence collection methods used by investigators.
